The family of a    boy snatched by an alligator at a Disney resort said Thursday that they were “devastated” by the child’s death and asked “for privacy during this extremely difficult time.
A Disney official said Wednesday the company plans to “thoroughly review” its alligator warning signage around a resort where a    boy was killed by a reptile that snatched him out of shallow water.
The Florida resort did not have signage warning of alligators in the water, and the company will “thoroughly review the situation for the future,” a Disney official said.
The resort had ”No Swimming” signs where the boy was killed at the Seven Seas Lagoon, but did not specifically mention alligators.
Some had questioned whether signs specifically warning of alligators should have been placed at the luxury property.

The Graves family was at a movie night outdoors Tuesday night at the Grand Floridian resort when the boy waded into about a foot of water in Seven Seas Lagoon, authorities have said.

They relaxed on the   beach that stretches along Disney’s luxe Grand Floridian Resort and Spa, one of the features the hotel uses to entice its guests, and they watched their young son wade   into the lake known by vacationers as Seven Seas Lagoon.

A troubled week for Disney, Body found intact, A dive team found the boy’s body intact in 6 feet of murky water about 10 to 15 yards from where he was attacked, Orange County Sheriff Jerry Demings said Wednesday.

Divers found the boy’s body “completely intact” about six feet beneath the surface of the massive,   lagoon, not far from the area where he was attacked the previous night, Orange County Sheriff Jerry Demings said Wednesday afternoon.
” Demings said that the body was in water roughly six feet deep,   yards from the edge of the lagoon where the child had been wading Tuesday night.

The alligator made off with the boy, and an intense search for him yielded nothing in the wide, murky expanse of water until more than 16 hours later, early on Wednesday afternoon, when divers found him about six feet below the surface and only 10 to 15 feet from where he had last been seen.
